values.alignmentText: Auckland and Wellington keep a steady stream of government and enterprise .NET contracts, but the market is small enough that Trey would need to weave in remote clients between local engagements.
Most urban areas average around 7 µg/m³ PM2.5 so the kids can play outside freely, yet winter wood-smoke inversions in Christchurch or Nelson mean we would keep a purifier handy for sensitive days.
Nearly half the population reports no religion, letting Sarah and Trey raise the boys secularly with only occasional Christian defaults in school ceremonies to navigate.
Independent courts, MMP elections, and watchdog media keep democratic scores in the global top tier, aligning with the family’s demand for resilient institutions.
Contactless EFTPOS and instant bank-to-bank transfers make day-to-day spending effortless, though cross-border fees stay high enough that we would maintain a US fintech account for savings moves.
Coastal cities give the family easy beach access for weekend play, yet cooler Pacific water and strong UV push us toward wetsuits and vigilant sun care.
Auckland’s board-game cafés and Wellington meetups give Trey outlets, but finding regular tables outside the main metros still takes proactive planning.
Subsidies exist yet long waitlists in Auckland mean Sarah and Trey would juggle paid care with neighbor networks to cover full-time work.
Compact neighborhoods, plentiful playgrounds, and low violent crime let the boys range independently while we monitor traffic in older suburbs.
20 Hours ECE and Best Start payments trim preschool costs for citizens, but infants still run NZ$350+ per week so families budget carefully until school age.
Temporary visa households access the 20 Hours ECE program, yet most income-tested subsidies stay off-limits, leaving higher out-of-pocket care costs.
Weekend tramping clubs, bouldering gyms, and vibrant indie game scenes give both adults plenty of outlets, with rugby culture easy to join as casual fans.
Kiwi neighborliness and active parent-teacher groups make it simple to build a community net, even if newcomers need to show up consistently at first.
Accredited Employer and Skilled Migrant visas spell out income and health hurdles, but shifting annual salary bands mean we must track policy updates to stay compliant.
Groceries, power, and childcare in Auckland or Wellington run 20–30% above US averages, so the family would trade a smaller home or move to secondary cities to balance the budget.
New Zealand allows dual nationality, letting the family keep US passports while naturalizing once residency requirements are met.
The economy is stable but sluggish after 2023’s technical recession, with high interest rates tempering hiring in tech and construction.
A liberal market economy with strong agricultural exports coexists with targeted social programs, matching the family’s comfort with regulated capitalism.
Curriculum refreshes keep classrooms student-centered, yet falling PISA math scores mean we would supplement with home resources for the boys.
Employer sponsorship hinges on accredited companies and high salary thresholds, so Trey would target a short list of larger firms or remote-first roles.
Dramatic landscapes and low particulate pollution align with the family’s love of nature, even though dairying runoff and invasive species strain rivers and biodiversity.
Progressive brackets and 15% GST put the household near a 30–33% effective rate, comparable to Seattle but without US deductions.
Autumn days hover near 14–20 °C (57–68 °F) in the North Island, which suits Sarah’s mild-climate preference while the South Island brings cooler rain fronts.
Family-friendly work policies and safe neighborhoods support the boys’ routines, though relatives will be far away for backup care.
Partner and dependent visas arrive with open work rights, keeping both adults employed once the main applicant qualifies.
Citizens receive 26 weeks of paid parental leave, Working for Families tax credits, and flexible work rights, covering much of the family’s desired safety net.
Policy defaults assume a two-parent household, yet flexible leave and shared-care arrangements support blended or nontraditional families reasonably well.
Many cash benefits require residence or citizenship, so newcomers lean on employer policies and universal health coverage until status upgrades.
Women’s style centers on practical layers, rain shells, and casual dresses, so Sarah can blend in without overhauling her wardrobe.
Men favor smart-casual layers and weatherproof gear, matching Trey’s existing mix of tech hoodies and outdoor wear.
Gender expression is relaxed, with workplace norms supporting women in leadership and dads taking leave, which aligns with the family’s progressive stance.
Studios like Wētā Workshop, Grinding Gear, and PikPok sustain a modest industry, so Trey could find opportunities but should expect limited senior openings.

As noted in Game Dev Work Prospects, Studios like Wētā Workshop, Grinding Gear, and PikPok sustain a modest industry, so Trey could find opportunities but should expect limited senior openings. Hiring velocity at established studios in New Zealand is moderate, with teams needing a few months to land the right hire.

Compensation clusters around global medians, requiring negotiation to balance cost of living. When opportunities surface in New Zealand, established studios benchmark offers against peers across the ecosystem.
Established studios in New Zealand rely on English for cross-border collaboration, while local-language fluency remains important for community, compliance, and platform partnerships.
Remote expectations at established studios in New Zealand are mixed—teams juggle on-site collaboration with hybrid arrangements when possible.
Legal recognition of gender diversity and community support in major cities give the boys exposure to inclusive norms from an early age.
Equal pay audits, legal abortion access, and high female political representation deliver the protections the family expects.
Dual-income households and normalized paternal leave help Trey and Sarah share caregiving without stigma.
New arrivals need IRD numbers, private insurance during the first two years, and proof of tenancy for schools, all manageable with upfront paperwork.
Sea-level rise threatens low-lying suburbs and stronger cyclones like Gabrielle show up every few years, so we would avoid coastal housing.
Public care is universal but specialist waitlists stretch months, meaning we’d keep private insurance for faster pediatric visits.
Work visas of two years or more unlock public care, yet shorter stays require private coverage and upfront GP fees.
Universities in Auckland, Wellington, Christchurch, and Dunedin are accessible with student loans, though tuition and housing costs push families to plan early savings.
International tuition stays high until residency, so the boys would need scholarships or PR before tertiary study becomes affordable.
Tight rental markets, aging insulation, and frequent bidding wars in Auckland mean the family either pays premium rents or targets smaller regional cities.
PAYE withholding, prefilled returns, and the myIR portal keep compliance simple once we register for IRD numbers.
State schools are free and zoned, but quality varies by decile so we’d choose housing carefully to land in strong catchments.
Children on work or resident visas attend public schools as domestic students, yet temporary visas under two years face international fees.
English dominates everyday life while Te Reo Māori signage adds bilingual flair without impeding the family’s integration.
Marriage equality, adoption rights, and visible Pride events keep the social climate welcoming for a polyamory-positive household.
Politics lean centrist with active labor parties, yet pro-market consensus means overt socialist policies remain niche.
Workplaces encourage men to take parental leave and share caregiving, aligning with Trey’s parenting style.
Tech, parenting, and board-game meetups run regularly in big cities, but smaller towns rely on Facebook groups to self-organize.
The NZ$23.15 minimum wage tracks living costs reasonably well yet still lags the Living Wage, so service workers often need dual incomes.
Fiber broadband and modern airports serve the metros, but aging water pipes and limited intercity rail create periodic disruptions.
Glaciers, fjords, and geothermal parks put world-class scenery within a few hours of any city, matching the family’s love of the outdoors.
Seismic faults, volcanic zones, and severe storms like Cyclone Gabrielle make emergency kits and earthquake insurance non-negotiable.
Regional parks, Great Walks, and surf breaks are close enough for regular family adventures without long drives.
Auckland and Wellington host lively live-music circuits, yet smaller cities wind down early so date nights take planning.
Metros stay open late with safe late-night transit, while regional towns quiet after midnight, which fits the family’s low-key habits.
NZGDA meetups and the annual NZGDC give Trey access to peers, though events remain concentrated in Auckland and Wellington.
Studios such as Grinding Gear Games, RocketWerkz, and Balancing Monkey offer collaborative ecosystems even if headcounts stay modest.
Creative grants, the CODE incubator, and film-tax incentives help, but venture funding is thin so Trey would still bootstrap an indie studio.

Startup founders report that Creative grants, the CODE incubator, and film-tax incentives help, but venture funding is thin so Trey would still bootstrap an indie studio. Hiring velocity at early-stage studios in New Zealand is moderate, with teams needing a few months to land the right hire.
Compensation clusters around global medians, requiring negotiation to balance cost of living. Early teams in New Zealand balance cash and equity to stay competitive while managing runway.
Founding teams in New Zealand lean on English for investor and platform communication, while local-language fluency helps with hiring, compliance, and community outreach.
Remote expectations among startups in New Zealand are mixed—teams juggle on-site collaboration with hybrid arrangements when possible.
Outside of Auckland, commutes stay short and shops close earlier, giving Sarah the slower rhythm she wants for family time.
Schools emphasize outdoor play and resilience, dovetailing with the family’s preference for balanced academics and free time.
Citizenship follows five years of residence with strict physical-presence totals, so the family must stay rooted while navigating paperwork.
Transparency International consistently ranks New Zealand among the least corrupt, satisfying the household’s demand for clean governance.
Mixed-member proportional elections and coalition governance keep policy responsive and pluralistic, aligning with the family’s progressive politics.
Poly groups meet openly in Auckland and Wellington, yet legal frameworks remain monogamy-centric so we would stay discreet with schools and landlords.
Licensed centers and kindergartens cover most suburbs, though popular Auckland neighborhoods still require joining waitlists during pregnancy.
Independent and integrated schools exist but carry NZ$15k–25k tuition, so private options become a selective backup rather than the norm.
Policies on marriage equality, cannabis reform debates, and indigenous partnership echo the family’s progressive priorities.
Government messaging focuses on public health and national identity, generally transparent but occasionally paternalistic during crises.
Independent media and active fact-checkers keep spin low, so the family can rely on diverse news sources.
Auckland and Wellington have improving rail and bus networks, yet service gaps and weekend frequency drops mean the family would still keep a car.
Secular governance dominates national debates, so faith rarely intrudes on policy affecting the family.
Post-pandemic norms allow hybrid work in tech hubs, though time zones with the US require Trey to schedule late calls.
Resident visas typically follow two to three years on work permits with income tests, so planning for renewals and savings is essential.
NZ Super kicks in at 65 with modest payments, so homeowners fare best while renters need KiwiSaver contributions to stay comfortable.
New arrivals must live 10 of the years between 20 and 65 to access NZ Super, pushing the family to self-fund retirement if they relocate mid-career.
Until permanent residence is secured, employer KiwiSaver contributions are limited and government pensions remain out of reach.
Ruby roles cluster in a few startups and consultancies, so Sarah would likely rely on remote US work or retrain toward more in-demand stacks.
Violent crime rates stay low and community policing is active, with petty theft around transit hubs the main issue to watch.
Public schools dominate and perform well, but international curricula and secular private options are limited outside Auckland.
Summer sea temps reach 20–22 °C in the north yet stay chilly in the South Island, so longer swims need wetsuits for the kids.
The maritime climate keeps summers mild and winters damp, matching the family’s dislike of extremes while demanding rain gear year-round.
Comprehensive sex education and open public discourse make it easy to raise sex-positive kids without stigma.
Progress on LGBTQ+ rights, reproductive care, and indigenous partnership aligns with the family’s social priorities.
Spring ranges from 12–18 °C (54–64 °F) in the North Island with frequent showers, while the South runs cooler but brightens quickly.
Political turnover is orderly, and public debt remains moderate, giving the family confidence in long-term plans.
Governments swing between center-left and center-right coalitions, blending social investment with market reforms.
Open markets with consumer protections let entrepreneurs thrive while keeping monopolies in check.
Summer highs sit near 20–26 °C (68–79 °F) with strong UV, keeping things comfortable if we manage midday sun.
Visa processing routinely stretches beyond six months and application fees top NZ$4,000 for a family, so we’d budget both time and money for the move.
Surveys show sustained trust in Parliament and public health agencies, which supports the family’s desire for transparent governance.
Corruption cases tend to be minor local procurement issues, not systemic bribery, matching the family’s low tolerance for graft.
Senior dev salaries cluster around NZ$120k–140k, covering basics but requiring side projects or remote gigs to match US earnings.
Weekends revolve around beach trips, tramping clubs, and Saturday markets, giving the boys plenty of outdoor time while Sundays stay quieter.
Primary schools run roughly 9 a.m.–3 p.m. and offices 8:30 a.m.–5 p.m., so after-school programs to 6 p.m. bridge both adults’ workdays.
Four weeks of statutory leave plus public holidays provide reliable downtime as long as we book early around Christmas closures.
Most tech employers stick close to the 20-day floor with occasional company shutdowns, so extra rest days require tenure or negotiation.
Kiwis joke about Australia yet maintain cooperative ties across the Tasman, fostering friendly regional sentiment.
National identity emphasizes fairness, outdoor life, and independence—values that resonate with the family.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Australia and Pacific neighbors generally view New Zealand as stable and eco-conscious, reinforcing a positive regional reputation.
Skilled Migrant and Entrepreneur visas exist but run on points, salary thresholds, and capped quotas, so the family must present strong credentials.
Americans integrate easily culturally, yet annual residence caps and strict biosecurity mean entry still feels selective.
The mix of thriving indie tech, Māori culture, and wild landscapes checks every box the family lists for an adventurous move.
Winters hover around 8–14 °C (46–57 °F) in the north and drop to 5–10 °C (41–50 °F) in the south with damp chill, so insulation upgrades matter.
A standard 40-hour week is the norm, with overtime less common but still appearing in peak product cycles.
Teams expect employees to log off by early evening, supporting Sarah’s need for predictable family dinners.
Collective bargaining coverage and strong safety laws protect employees, even though union membership is voluntary.
Frequent abrupt changes make certain months feel unstable with several days of hazardous conditions that push us indoors.
Deep winter gloom lasts several weeks, so we plan strict routines, supplements, and possible getaways to maintain morale.
Roughly half the year is wonderful, half demands planning around heat, cold, or rain to enjoy time outside.
Basic needs are met but savings and extracurriculars are hard to sustain without extra support or side work.
Housing and childcare strain the budget, limiting savings and discretionary spending most months.
Affluent households encounter noticeable friction—specialists, tutors, or clubs are scarce or highly gated.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Only a handful of listings surface each year; expect bidding wars and significant trade-offs.
We can find a few reputable co-living or cooperative projects though demand may require patience.
Locals are polite and willing to connect when we show initiative, though relationships build gradually.
Generally welcoming yet periodic political rhetoric creates mild concern.
Mostly comfortable integration though some circles question motives or commitment to the country.
Friendly exchanges happen when we initiate; staff and strangers respond positively.
Relationships deepen steadily with consistent effort; vulnerability is appreciated though not automatic.
Most locals read body language well, though some settings skew closer than we prefer.
People appreciate directness and respond constructively when we share concerns or needs.
We feel a gentle push to stay polished in professional or social spaces.
We notice subtle comparisons; maintaining confidence requires occasional boundary setting.
Certain districts expect polished outfits, though flexibility exists in family spaces.
Most encounters are considerate though occasional missteps require direct communication.
Mostly flexible though some circles still expect traditional roles on first approach.
Supportive subcultures exist and mainstream spaces remain tolerant if discreet. non-monogamy acceptance.
Attitudes split; open discussion is fine in urban enclaves yet frowned upon elsewhere.
Acceptance exists within progressive scenes and is tolerated publicly with respectful curiosity.
Crowded transit aside, locals check before touching and notice discomfort.
Guns are present yet culturally treated as tools with strong safety expectations.
Light penalties and robust health services keep substance issues managed compassionately.
Most enforcement is targeted though occasional crackdowns create unease.
Occasional events occur regionally, prompting situational awareness but not chronic fear.
Prisons meet international standards with active oversight and restorative programs.
Infrastructure is inconsistent; safe walking requires choosing specific neighborhoods.
Health-conscious communities exist alongside more laid-back groups; resources are readily available.
Ultra-processed options crowd shelves; schools and events lean heavily on packaged snacks.
We can meet most cravings but specialty ingredients or restaurants appear sporadically.
Mental health burdens exist but are met with accessible services and open dialogue.
We monitor diet and activity because obesity is moderately common.
Rates align with global norms; screening and early detection programs are reliable.
Recessions hit noticeable segments, requiring flexibility or retraining.
